title: Asim Umar Killed In Afghanistan, Economic Slowdown 'More Pronounced' In India + Other Top News
text:
Asim Umar, the head of the Al-Qaeda in South Asia was killed in a joint operation the Afghan and US forces, Afghan authorities have said.

According to the National Directorate of Security (NDS), Umar was killed in a raid on a Taliban compound in Helmand province on 23 September.

NDS also stated that six others were also killed along with him in the raid. The NDS described Umar as a Pakistani citizen, like the others who were also killed in the same operation.

Though Umar held Pakistani citizenship, he was born in Sambhal, in Uttar Pradesh. He had reportedly migrated to Pakistan in the 1990s and later acquired citizenship there. Read More.

Effects Of Global Economic Slowdown ‘More Pronounced’ In India, Says IMF Chief

Even as jobs are increasingly being lost in India and an economic crisis has presumably come to grip the country, there is little signs of relief coming in the near future and the trigger warning has now come from the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

As the global economy is witnessing "synchronized slowdown", the effect is "more pronounced" this year in some of the largest emerging market economies like India, said the new International Monetary Fund (IMF) Managing Director, Kristalina Georgieva. Read More





As Yet Another Stubble Burning Season Is Set To Begin, Delhi Is Gearing Up For Sky-High Pollution Levels Yet Again

As reports of isolated cases of stubble burning begin to emerge from Punjab and Haryana, national capital New Delhi is bracing for toxic air days.

This year so far had been good, with both Delhi and Gurugram registering the cleanest September in many years.

The air quality of Delhi-NCR is set to plummet as the winter set in, due to the Diwali festivities and the stubble burning in neighboring states. However, there are no plans or strategies to address the crisis this year too. Read More





Iranian Women To Watch Football Match In Stadium Without Restrictions For First Time In 40 Years

Iranian women will taste freedom to enter football stadium without any restrictions in decades after FIFA threatened to suspend the Islamic republic over its controversial male-only policy.

After decades of being banned from male sporting events, Iranian women will be able to enter a football stadium on Thursday. Iran has barred female spectators from football and other stadiums for around 40 years, with cleric arguing that women must be shielded from the masculine atmosphere and sight of semi-clad men. Read More





Slowdown Everywhere: Even United Nations Doesn’t Have Enough Money To Pay Its Staff

Reports of unemployment and layoffs are rife these days in both India as well as several other countries throughout the globe but the crisis is so deep that even the United Nations (UN) is not spared.

The UN may not have enough money for staff salaries next month if member states don’t pay what they owe, news agency Reuters quoted U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres as saying. Read More
